Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Readme] Too much whitespace at the top of a readme file " (#8508) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Repro:

Upload a package with an embedded readme file through Gallery.

The upload page shows too much whitespace at the top:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41028779/113797793-ce335280-9706-11eb-9caf-7aff54b54838.png)

The same thing at the manage package page:

@loic-sharma

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Readme] A message should be provided about when the readme file will be available." (#8507) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Upload a package with an embedded readme file, and check these messages we provide.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Fix culture and line endings issues in tests" (#7778) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Fix some tests failures:

* Due to bad line endings in xml resources. Replaced to xml entities  `
` 

* If current culture is not invariant some tests fail due to exception messages are localized while assert strings are not. So it would be better to have localized strings in tests.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "CloudAuditService preparing for secret refresh" (#8486) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Changed `CloudAuditService` to use `ICloudBlobClient` to access blob storage instead of using SDK classes directly, so it is ready for secret refresh changes. Also, DI registration was updated to resolve all dependencies within DI container instead of pulling in values from closures, which should help with secret refresh, too.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add the project type `nfproj` to the list of supportedProjectExtensions for Nuget CLI." (#10562) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: NuGet.exe

Product version: latest

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: none.

## Repro steps and/or sample project

**Proposal:**
Add the project type `nfproj` to the list of supportedProjectExtensions in `NuGet.Client/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.CommandLine/Common/ProjectHelper.cs`
A PR can be raised if required.

**Further explanation:**
.NET nanoFramework (https://dotnetfoundation.org/projects/nanoframework) is an OSS platform that enables the writing of managed code applications for constrained embedded devices. It is supported by the .NET foundation.
.NET nanoFramework uses nuget packages extensively, however, due to a lack of support in VS for extensibility to have sub-projects in a given language (C#), we could not use the standard `csproj` type and have had to differentiate our projects by using a `nfproj` file extension. 
When performing automated dependency updates, currently nuget CLI does not recognise this extension and we have to perform a workaround of scripting the rename of these projects to be the standard `csproj` in order to run tasks like `nuget update`, and then reverse the rename for compatibility with VS.
This is far from ideal, and by adding support for the extension in nuget, it would alleviate a number of complex workarounds.

### Verbose Logs

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "TfmSpecificPackageFile .targets file is causing NU1012 when running dotnet pack with 5.0.201" (#10724) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

```
dotnet --list-sdks
3.0.101 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
3.1.402 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
5.0.100 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
5.0.200-preview.21077.7 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
5.0.201 [C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk]
```
Microsoft Visual Studio Enterprise 2019 Preview
Version 16.10.0 Preview 1.0 

## Repro steps and/or sample project
I have a WPF NuGet package that contains a custom .targets file to extend the build process of consumers. The full project is [XAMLTest](https://github.com/Keboo/XAMLTest), but I have created a smaller [sample project](https://github.com/Keboo/PackIssue) the reproduces the issue as well. In order to get the targets files into the needed `build\<tfm>` directory I have been using the [TfmSpecificPackageFile](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/msbuild-targets#targetsfortfmspecificcontentinpackage) extensibility to inject the targets files. 


In the repository I have included a global.json file for switching between 5.0.100 and 5.0.201. The following steps work under 5.0.100, but throw a NU1012 when run with 5.0.201

1. Set .NET version in global.json
2. Run dotnet pack

With 5.0.100 a NuGet package is generated with the targets file placed within build\<tfm>\.
With 5.0.201 I received the error
>  C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\5.0.201\Sdks\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack\build\NuGet.Build.Tasks.Pack.targets(221,5): error NU1012: Some included files are included under TFMs which are missing a platform version: net5.0-windows [D:\Dev\PackIssue\PackIssue\PackIssue.csproj]

I have attempted to determine how to properly set the "platform version" that it cares about, but have been unable to find the needed configuration value to set. Perhaps it is as simple as knowing the needed configuration?
The issue only reproduces when using `net5.0-windows` removing the `-windows` allows for the package to be built successfully as well. However, since my goal is to distrubte a WPF package this is not a viable solution for me as I need to set `<UseWPF>true</USeWPF>`.
In my XAMLTest project, I am able to use the same `TfmSpecificPackageFile` extensibility with `.exe` and `.json` files without an error on both 5.0.100 and 5.0.201. 

[VerboseLog.txt](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/6259457/VerboseLog.txt)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue ".nupkg.metadata missing when executing 'nuget add -Expand' from  Azure DevOps MSBuild task" (#10701) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Please read the following information before posting the issue. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet client tools (the Visual Studio extension, NuGet.exe command line tool, etc.), you are in the right place. -->
<!-- If you're having trouble with the NuGet.org Website, please post in [NuGetGallery issues](http://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues) -->

## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | MSBuild.exe):

Product version: 4.7.1, 5.8.1, 5.9.0

## Repro steps and/or sample project

Hi,

We're using the -Expand option in a MSBuild task to publish newly generated NuGet packages to a local fallback folder (see below).

```
<Target Name="PublishLocalNugetPackage" AfterTargets="Pack;DeleteExistingLocalNuGetPackage">                
  <Exec Command="nuget add $(PackageOutputPath)$(PackageId).$(Version).nupkg -Expand -Source $(LocalNugetFeedPath) -Verbosity detailed"/>
</Target>
```

This works beautifully when invoking MSBuild from the command line. However, when we use the `MSBuild@1` task in our Azure DevOps pipeline, (everything seems to go just fine, no errors or anything) we end up with an expanded package that is missing the `.nupkg.metadata` file (see images below), which seems to cause subsequent steps that use the fallback folder to fail with the following error (package id ommitted):

`Error NU1101: Unable to find package <PACKAGEID>. No packages exist with this id in source(s): Project.Tools, nuget.org` 

_Build agent output_
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5137829/112953964-3b127f80-913e-11eb-8dbe-7949e78faa06.png)

_MSBuild command executed manually (same machine)_
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5137829/112954000-4796d800-913e-11eb-8922-28deb91192b8.png)

I'd like to get some confirmation that the missing `.nupkg.metadata` file is indeed causing the issue that subsequent steps that rely on the fallback folder are failing and if so, what we can do to solve the issue.

Thanks! 

### Verbose Logs
(package id ommitted)
```
15>PublishLocalNugetPackage:
         NuGet Version: 4.7.1.5393
         Acquiring lock for the installation of <PACKAGEID> 3.0.325
         Acquired lock for the installation of <PACKAGEID> 3.0.325
         Installing <PACKAGEID> 3.0.325.
         Completed installation of <PACKAGEID> 3.0.325
         Successfully added package 'C:\agent\_work\2\s\nuget\nupkg\Release\<PACKAGEID>.3.0.325.nupkg' to feed 'C:\agent\_work\2\s\nuget\project-local\'.
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Package restore fails on Ubuntu 20 with This package was not repository signed with a certificate listed by this repository." (#10723) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS
dotnet SDK 5.0.102

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 
It works fine on Windows.

## Repro steps and/or sample project

```ps1
dotnet new classlib
dotnet add package Nerdbank.GitVersioning --version 3.4.179-rc
```

```
  Determining projects to restore...
  Writing /tmp/tmpidqMU4.tmp
info : Adding PackageReference for package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning' into project '/tmp/nbgvtest/nbgvtest.csproj'.
info : Restoring packages for /tmp/nbgvtest/nbgvtest.csproj...
info :   CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/nerdbank.gitversioning/index.json
info :   CACHE https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/nerdbank.gitversioning/3.4.179-rc/nerdbank.gitversioning.3.4.179-rc.nupkg
info : Installing Nerdbank.GitVersioning 3.4.179-rc.
info : Package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning 3.4.179-rc' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Signature Hash Algorithm: SHA256
info : Package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning 3.4.179-rc' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Timestamp: 03/25/2021 06:05:34
info : Package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning 3.4.179-rc' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Verifying author primary signature's timestamp with timestamping service certificate:

info :   Subject Name: CN=DigiCert Timestamp 2021, O="DigiCert, Inc.", C=US
info :   SHA1 hash: E1D782A8E191BEEF6BCA1691B5AAB494A6249BF3
info :   SHA256 hash: B3109006BC0AD98307915729E04403415C83E3292B614F26964C8D3571ECF5A9
info :   Issued by: CN=DigiCert SHA2 Assured ID Timestamping CA, OU=www.digicert.com, O=DigiCert Inc, C=US
info :   Valid from: 12/31/2020 17:00:00 to 01/05/2031 17:00:00
info : Package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning 3.4.179-rc' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Signature type: Author
info : Package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning 3.4.179-rc' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': Verifying the author primary signature with certificate:
info :   Subject Name: CN=Nerdbank (.NET Foundation), O=Nerdbank (.NET Foundation), L=Redmond, S=Washington, C=US, SERIALNUMBER=603 389 068
info :   SHA1 hash: FCDF2332A1D8DB415EA421193F7AC5A6BD4F515D
info :   SHA256 hash: 1F891E64936D15DE5FAE22D910CD39F3E9860213C92F20CF9638A245B1249D2B
info :   Issued by: CN=.NET Foundation Projects Code Signing CA, O=.NET Foundation, C=US
info :   Valid from: 03/08/2020 18:00:00 to 03/14/2023 06:00:00
error: NU3034: Package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning 3.4.179-rc' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': This package was not repository signed with a certificate listed by this repository.
info : Package 'Nerdbank.GitVersioning' is compatible with all the specified frameworks in project '/tmp/nbgvtest/nbgvtest.csproj'.
error: Value cannot be null. (Parameter 'path1')
```

Note that:
1. the new project has no nuget.config to even require signed packages. 
2. version 3.3.37 of the same package installs just fine. (nuget.org used a different cert to sign it between these two versions)
3. Besides the claim about not being signed, there's also an ArgumentNullException error message on the last line, suggesting another(?) bug.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.org temporarily down due to Azure services outage" (#57) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
NuGet.org is being affected by an outage due to issues affecting the Azure Portal and Azure services, but the team is on it. We appreciate your patience and we will keep you updated as soon as we get more information.

In the meantime, check https://status2.azure.com/ for Azure updates and find work-arounds in this thread https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8480.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Notice: NuGet Restore Failures on Linux distributions using NSS or Mozilla root CA list" (#56) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
## Context

Users of .NET 5.0+ will receive error messages when running `dotnet restore` on Linux distros that use [nss](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/) or `ca-certificates` packages maintained by Mozilla's root CA list. The root cause is due to the certificate used for signed NuGet packages recently expiring and as a result the validation for packages uses a timestamp provider chain that has a root certificate that has been [removed by Network Security Services (NSS)](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1686854) which is a popular alternative to [OpenSSL](https://github.com/openssl/openssl).

- [NuGet Microsoft Author Signing Certificate Update](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/microsoft-author-signing-certificate-update/) - Expires January 27th, 2021
- [NuGet.org Repository Signing Certificate Update](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/) - Expires April 14th, 2021

For more information, please read the [Distrust of Symantec TLS Certificates](https://blog.mozilla.org/security/2018/03/12/distrust-symantec-tls-certificates/) on the Mozilla Security Blog, [Mozilla Root Store Policy](https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/about/governance/policies/security-group/certs/policy/) on Mozilla.org, and [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues) on the Mozilla Wiki Page.

## Affected Environments

.NET 5.0+ SDK on Linux distros that use [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes). 

At this time, we are not sure of every distro that may be affected. If you're aware of an affected distro, please let us know!

Below is a table that includes .NET support for Linux distros:

### Linux

OS                                    | Version               | Affected          |
--------------------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------|
[Alpine Linux][Alpine]                | N/A                 | ❓ |
[CentOS][CentOS]                      | N/A                    | ❓ |
[Debian][Debian]                      | N/A                    | ❓ |
[Fedora][Fedora]                      | N/A                   | ❓ |
[Linux Mint][Linux-Mint]              | N/A                   | ❓ |
[openSUSE][OpenSUSE]                  | N/A                   | ❓ |
[Red Hat Enterprise Linux][RHEL]      | N/A                    | ❓ |
[SUSE Enterprise Linux (SLES)][SLES]  | N/A               | ❓ |
[Ubuntu][Ubuntu]                      | N/A   | ❓ |

[Alpine]: https://alpinelinux.org/
[CentOS]: https://www.centos.org/
[Debian]: https://www.debian.org/
[Fedora]: https://getfedora.org/
[Linux-Mint]: https://linuxmint.com/
[OpenSUSE]: https://opensuse.org/
[RHEL]: https://www.redhat.com/en/technologies/linux-platforms/enterprise-linux
[SLES]: https://www.suse.com/products/server/
[Ubuntu]: https://ubuntu.com/

Additionally, here is a table of other Linux variants that may be affected but are not officially supported by .NET.

OS                                    | Version               | Affected       |
--------------------------------------|-----------------------|-------------------|
[Arch Linux](https://archlinux.org/)                          | 20210328+                 | ✅[Issue](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10695)             |
[Artix Linux](https://artixlinux.org/)                         | 20201128+                    | ✅[Issue](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10684)             |

### Other Linux distros

- At the time of writing, we believe other distributions will not be affected until a distribution is updated to include [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes).

## Mitigation

### .NET Core 3.1

.NET 5 introduces a signing verification mechanism that promotes warnings to throw an error at `dotnet restore` time. To work around this, you can temporarily target against .NET Core 3.1.

### Modify CA Certificate Store

Depending on your Linux distro, you can modify your CA certificate store by taking on an earlier version of your `ca-certificates` package.

For reference, the affected version is [nss 3.63+](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Projects/NSS/NSS_3.63_release_notes). `nss` includes a hard-coded list of trusted CA certificates and therefore can be modified to include and trust the `Verisign Universal Root Certificate Authority` again.

Many Linux distros can leverage `dpkg-reconfigure` to check for the entry and enable trust for it. As a manual workaround, you may need to remove a `leading !` from the certificate line & update your CA certificates package.

**Note:** Doing this is considered a bad security practice & should only be done if you understand the security implications of doing so.

## Solution

Due to existing issues with the .NET 5 signing verification feature & fallback of timestamp verification, we have decided to revoke this feature for Unix-based systems within .NET 5 SDK. Therefore your experience of using `dotnet restore` will remain largely the same as it was in .NET Core 3.1. Stay tuned for an updated .NET SDK version that will include this change.

### Stay updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We will also continue posting updates on [NuGet Status](https://status.nuget.org/) and [@NuGet on Twitter](https://twitter.com/nuget).

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Package Namespaces Proposal" (#55) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Introduction of a feature concept called Package Namespaces which allows a developer to include or exclude package IDs by specifying package namespaces on their package source(s).

🎉📦Please provide your comments, concerns, and feedback within this PR. 📦🎉

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/pull/10660

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Custom V2 OData queries will be deprecated March 9th, 2021 " (#54) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (#37) last year and conducted a dry run of the deprecation to ensure that there are no surprises for users (#40). 

We will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in March 9, 2021, as detailed in [the blogpost here](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/custom-v2-odata-queries-will-be-deprecated-march-9-2021/).

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post.](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021" (#53) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
The current NuGet.org repository signing certificate will be updated as soon as March 15th, 2021. If you validate that packages are repository signed by NuGet.org using a [NuGet client policy](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/consume-packages/installing-signed-packages), the [`NuGet.exe verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/reference/cli-reference/cli-ref-verify) command, or the [`dotnet nuget verify`](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-nuget-verify) command, you will need to take steps by March 15th, 2021 to avoid disruptions when installing packages from NuGet.org signed with the new certificate. 

If you are unsure if you will be impacted or want to see instructions to allow the new certificate, please see our blogpost on the matter: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/the-nuget-org-repository-signing-certificate-will-be-updated-as-soon-as-march-15th-2021/

Events.RelatedBody:

